title-group.article-title: A Direct Comparison Approach for Testing Measurement Invariance

contrib-group.aff: 1Department of Management, The Chinese University of Hong Kong, Shatin, Hong Kong
2Department of Management, The Open University of Hong Kong, Ho Man Tin, Hong Kong

author-notes.corresp: Gordon W. Cheung, Department of Management, The Chinese University of Hong Kong, Room 810, Cheng Yue Tung Building, CUHK, Shatin, NT, Hong Kong Email: gordonc@cuhk.edu.hk

fn.p: Gordon W. Cheung (PhD, Virginia Tech) is currently Professor of Management at The Chinese University of Hong Kong. His research interests include fit measures, measurement equivalence, and second-order models in structural equation modeling. He served as the Chair of the Research Methods Division of the Academy of Management in 2006/2007.

Rebecca S. Lau (PhD, Virginia Tech) is a lecturer of management at the Open University of Hong Kong. She conducts research on organizational research methods, particularly in the area of structural equation modeling. Her research interests also include leadership and exchange relationships with a focus on those among coworkers.

abstract.p: Measurement equivalence/invariance (ME/I) is a condition that should be met before meaningful comparisons of survey results across groups can be made. As an alternative to the likelihood ratio test (LRT), the change in comparative fit index (ΔCFI) rules of thumb, and the modification index (MI), this teaching note demonstrates the procedures for establishing bias-corrected (BC) bootstrap confidence intervals for testing ME/I. Unlike the LRT and ΔCFI methods, which need a different model estimation per item, the BC bootstrap confidence intervals approach can examine item-level ME/I tests using a single model. This method greatly simplifies the search for an invariant item as the reference indicator in the factor-ratio test. Also demonstrated here is how the factor-ratio test and the list-and-delete method can be extended from the metric invariance test to the scalar invariance test. Finally, the BC bootstrap confidence interval procedures for comparing uniqueness variances, factor variances, factor covariances, and latent means across groups are shown.

body.p: In the social sciences, a considerable amount of research aims to make comparisons across groups. These groups may be defined by cultures, genders, rater groups, and modes of measurement administration, such as Web-based versus paper-and-pencil measures, or they may consist of the same individuals measured at different points in time (i.e., stability of measurement over time; see Schmitt and Kuljanin, 2008, for a review of empirical studies). Before making meaningful comparisons of survey results across groups, researchers should ensure that respondents from different groups have ascribed similar meanings to the survey items. This requirement has put the topic of measurement equivalence/invariance (ME/I; Vandenberg & Lance, 2000) under the research spotlight.

ME/I involves comparisons of the various parameters of a measurement and structural equation model across groups. Although scholars recommend various possible sequences of ME/I tests in the literature (e.g., Cheung, 2008; Cheung & Rensvold, 2002; Vandenberg & Lance, 2000), the ME/I tests, as well as the sequence of tests required in a particular study, depend on the empirical questions under examination (Cheung, 2008). In this teaching note, we follow the eight-test sequence suggested by Cheung and Rensvold (2002). For cross-group comparisons, it is necessary to first establish configural invariance, which is also known as weak factorial invariance (Horn & McArdle, 1992), to ensure that the number of constructs and items associated with each construct are the same across groups (Meredith, 1993). After configural invariance is established, the remaining ME/I tests can be examined at three different levels. At Level 1, there is the configural invariance model with which the differences in factor loadings are estimated for testing metric invariance. Metric invariance, also known as strong factorial invariance (Horn & McArdle, 1992), exists when the factor loadings of the like items are invariant across groups. Next, at Level 2, using the metric invariance model, researchers can examine the invariance of uniqueness variances, factor variances, factor covariances, item intercepts, or path coefficients across groups. In other words, if researchers are interested in comparing construct variances and covariances or path coefficients across groups, establishment of configural and metric invariance alone is required because the estimation of construct variances and covariances and path coefficients does not involve item means and item intercepts (Cheung, 2008).

Finally, Level 3 involves the scalar invariance model for the comparison of latent means. If researchers are interested in comparing latent means across groups, configural, metric, and scalar invariances are necessary. An item intercept is the value of the item corresponding to the zero value of the underlying construct (Cheung & Rensvold, 2002). When the item slopes (factor loadings) and item intercepts are both invariant, the measurement scales share the same operational definition, including the same intervals and same zero points across groups, which further suggests that meaningful comparison of the latent means can be achieved. In contrast, when scalar invariance fails, the comparison of latent means becomes ambiguous because any difference in the latent means can be the result of a true between-group difference or a difference in the scale and origin of the latent variable. Accordingly, scalar invariance is a prerequisite for comparing latent means (Cheung & Rensvold, 2000). However, invariance in uniqueness variances is not required because measurement errors are accounted for when estimating other parameters with structural equation modeling (SEM). In addition, as factor variances and covariances are not assumed to be invariant across groups when testing latent mean equivalence, equivalence in factor variances and covariances needs not be tested. Strict factorial invariance (Meredith, 1993) that includes metric, scalar, and uniqueness variance equivalence is only required if observed means are compared across groups.

In practical applications, failure of full ME/I is not uncommon (Vandenberg & Lance, 2000), and researchers may choose to remove the noninvariant items from the measure, invoke partial ME/I in subsequent tests (Byrne, Shavelson, & Muthén, 1989; Marsh & Hocevar, 1985), or interpret the noninvariance as meaningful information (Cheung & Rensvold, 1999). As a result, with the establishment of configural invariance, researchers may base on a model with partial instead of full metric invariance for additional ME/I tests. Likewise, researchers may base on a model with partial metric and scalar invariance for comparing latent means. No matter whether a researcher chooses to remove the noninvariant item, establish a partial metric and scalar invariance model, or examine the implications of noninvariance, the researcher needs to identify the survey items that fail measurement invariance.

This teaching note serves three objectives. First, the bias-corrected (BC) bootstrap confidence interval approach, which has been recommended for testing mediation effects and comparing the strengths of mediation effects (Cheung & Lau, 2008; Lau & Cheung, 2012; MacKinnon, Lockwood, & Williams, 2004; Williams & MacKinnon, 2008), is extended to the test of ME/I. Unlike the likelihood ratio test (LRT) and the change in comparative fit index (ΔCFI) approach (Cheung & Rensvold, 2002; Meade, Johnson, & Braddy, 2008), which require different model estimations per item for item-level ME/I, we show that the BC bootstrap confidence interval approach can examine item-level metric invariance in a single model and can greatly simplify the factor-ratio test that resolves the reference indicator selection problem (Cheung & Rensvold, 1999). The second objective is to demonstrate the procedures for testing scalar invariance with the BC bootstrap confidence interval approach. We also show how the list-and-delete method (Rensvold & Cheung, 2001) can be used to identify sets of invariant items when full scalar invariance is rejected. Finally, we demonstrate how the BC bootstrap confidence interval procedures can be used to compare uniqueness variances, factor variances, factor covariances, and latent means across groups.

sec.title: Common Methods for Testing ME/I
sec.p: The methods that have been proposed for identifying noninvariant items can be grouped into two major categories: the confirmatory factor analysis (CFA) and item response theory frameworks (Millsap & Everson, 1993; Reise, Widaman, & Pugh, 1993). This teaching note is confined to testing ME/I in a CFA framework, which continues to be the method most frequently used in organizational research (Vandenberg & Lance, 2000). In the CFA framework for testing ME/I, a multiple-group confirmatory factor analysis model is created. Equality constraints are added to a set of parameters, such as factor loadings, in the measurement model across groups. The model fit of this constrained model is then compared to that of the unconstrained model to decide whether the equality constraints result in a worse fit. When comparing the model fit of the constrained and unconstrained models in testing ME/I, the LRT (the difference in χ2 between two nested models, ▵χ2; Bollen, 1989) is commonly used to examine whether the constrained model provides a more parsimonious model when the model fit is not significantly worse than that of the unconstrained model. Nonetheless, the use of ▵χ2 is subject to some limitations. Like the χ2 index of overall model fit, ▵χ2 is sensitive to sample size (Brannick, 1995; Kelloway, 1995). As a consequence, if the combined sample size of the groups being compared is large, even a small difference in the factor loadings (or other parameters) across groups may lead to a significant value of ▵χ2, which in turn would suggest that the null hypothesis of invariance be rejected (Rensvold & Cheung, 2001).

In view of this limitation, researchers have been investigating whether changes in fit indices (▵FIs) can be used in place of ▵χ2. Cheung and Rensvold (2002), for instance, have recommended the use of the ▵CFI such that a reduction in the value of the comparative fit index (CFI) smaller than or equal to 0.01 in the constrained model would suggest that the null hypothesis of invariance should not be rejected. As many fit indices, including the CFI, are derived from χ2, the recent development of various formulas for calculating χ2 (Jöreskog, 2004; Jöreskog & Sörbom, 2002) tends to complicate the use of the ▵CFI. Specifically, although some SEM programs (such as AMOS and Mplus) report CFIs derived from the minimum fit function χ2, other SEM programs (such as LISREL) report CFIs derived from normal theory weighted least squares χ2. Although the cutoff value suggested by Cheung and Rensvold (2002) was developed based on a CFI derived from the minimum fit function χ2, Meade et al. (2008) have recommended that a general cutoff value of 0.002 can be used for ▵CFIs derived from normal theory weighted least squares χ2.

The use of rules of thumb for testing ME/I can pose other problems. One pitfall of this approach is that the ▵CFI has no known sampling distribution and, hence, is not subject to any significance testing. These cutoff values may thus be criticized as arbitrary. In addition, scholars have been suggesting that the same cutoff values should not be applied to evaluate models that have different levels of complexity (e.g., Anderson & Gerbing, 1984; Cheung & Rensvold, 2002; Gerbing & Anderson, 1993). As the models for ME/I tested by researchers may be of various levels of complexity in terms of, for instance, the number of groups, the number of constructs, or the number of items per construct, the cutoff values recommended in the literature may not be sufficient to accommodate the effects of model complexity.

Another concern of using ▵χ2, ▵CFI, and ▵FIs in testing ME/I is that the tests are less powerful if the groups under comparison are of unequal sample size, which in turn may lead to failure to detect noninvariance. It has been found that ME/I tests that utilize changes in CFI, root mean square error of approximation (RMSEA), standardized root mean square residual (SRMR), Gamma hat, McDonald’s noncentrality index, and χ2 values are more powerful when the sample sizes are equal than when the sample sizes are unequal across groups and when there is a true population difference in factor loadings, item intercepts, and item residual variances (Chen, 2007). This may be due to the fact that when the groups being compared have unequal sample sizes, the one with the larger size will exert a greater influence on the parameter estimation process of the constrained model.

Another method involves the use of the modification index (MI) to examine whether full metric invariance holds across groups (Marsh & Hocevar, 1985; Yoon & Millsap, 2007). Specifically, if full metric invariance fails, the invariance constraints in the measurement model are relaxed sequentially based on MI values, starting with the loading that has the largest MI until no MI is significant or larger than a cutoff value, such as 5 or 10. However, MI values are estimated with the assumption that all other constrained parameters in the fully constrained model are correct, or in other words, all the other factor loadings are invariant—except the one being relaxed. If more than one of the constrained factor loadings is in fact noninvariant, the assumption will be invalid and may lead to inaccurate identification of noninvariant items (Cheung & Rensvold, 1999). In a recent simulation study, it was found that the proportion of false detections can be as high as 31% with a sample size of 200 and 24% with a sample size of 500 in a six-item, one-construct model with medium loading difference in two items (Yoon & Millsap, 2007).

sec.title: Referent Item Selection
sec.p: The issue of referent item selection was raised by Cheung and Rensvold about a decade ago (Cheung & Rensvold, 1999; Rensvold & Cheung, 2001). Researchers need to define the unit of measurement for latent variables in any structural equation model. Two methods are used in general: standardizing the construct variance or setting the factor loading of a selected item (the referent) to unity. Nevertheless, both methods have shortcomings in testing metric invariance (Cheung & Rensvold, 1999). Specifically, standardizing the construct variance assumes that the variances of the construct are equal across groups, which may be untenable especially in cross-national comparisons where the samples are drawn from two populations (Cheung & Rensvold, 2000). Similarly, setting the factor loading of a selected item to unity makes an a priori assumption that the true factor loadings of the referent are equal across groups. It is possible, however, that the researcher inadvertently selects an item that is not metric invariant as the referent. In this case, the validity of the results of the metric invariance test may be jeopardized (refer to Cheung & Rensvold, 1999, Appendix B, for a detailed mathematical demonstration), as may the results from subsequent tests following this test of metric invariance (Vandenberg, 2002). A recent study shows that if a noninvariant item is chosen to be the referent, the results of the item-level ME/I tests can be very misleading (Johnson, Meade, & DuVernet, 2009). Although the ideal situation is that the researcher selects an item that demonstrates metric invariance as the referent (Steenkamp & Baumgartner, 1998), in practice researchers seldom know a priori which items are invariant and which are not before conducting any test of metric invariance.

To solve this problem, the factor-ratio test was proposed for testing metric invariance (Cheung & Rensvold, 1999). Instead of selecting one item for each construct as the referent, researchers conduct a systematic examination of all models that use different items as referents. In each model, the factor loading of the argument (the item being tested for invariance) with a particular referent is constrained to be invariant across groups. For a construct containing n items, a total of n(n – 1)/2 constrained models are estimated (Cheung & Rensvold, 1999; Rensvold & Cheung, 2001). The model fit of the constrained model is then compared to that of the globally unconstrained model. This test thus allows researchers to identify the noninvariant item (or items) with respect to each referent in a noninvariant construct. Although a recent simulation study has shown that this test can correctly identify noninvariant items (French & Finch, 2008), the repeated model estimation requirement makes the approach tedious and less attractive (Yoon & Millsap, 2007).

sec.title: BC Bootstrap Confidence Intervals
sec.p: The use of BC bootstrap confidence intervals is an extension of the estimation of confidence intervals for factor loading differences proposed by Meade and Bauer (2007) and the use of BC bootstrap confidence intervals for testing differences in indirect effects across groups (Lau & Cheung, 2012). The procedure simply creates 1,000 bootstrap samples, calculates the parameters (such as the differences in factor loadings or intercepts) for each bootstrap sample, and finally makes adjustments to the bootstrap distribution of the parameters to form the confidence intervals. If zero falls outside of a confidence interval, then the null hypothesis of invariance will be rejected. With BC bootstrap confidence intervals, researchers not only can examine multiple parameters across groups simultaneously but also can get an estimate of the parameter as well as a confidence interval for the estimate. Although researchers can also estimate the magnitude of the difference after rejecting invariance using the LRT, ▵CFI, and MI approaches, the standard error of the difference is not readily available. As the method proposed by Meade and Bauer (2007, pp. 613-614) derives the confidence interval for the difference between factor loadings from the standard errors of the two loading estimates by assuming that the covariance term in the estimation of the standard error is zero, it is only suitable for cross-group comparisons and not for comparisons involving the same group, such as latent growth models (e.g., Chan, 1998), multirater analysis (e.g., Cheung, 1999), and latent congruence models (Cheung, 2009). The BC bootstrap confidence interval approach, on the contrary, does not have this limitation and can be used for both cross-group and within-group comparisons. The use of BC bootstrap confidence intervals also corrects the bias in the bootstrapped sampling distribution. As the bootstrapped sampling distribution may be a biased estimation of the sampling distribution, adjustment of the bootstrapped sampling distribution improves the accuracy of the inferences made about the true population values of the differences concerned. The BC bootstrap method thus provides more accurate confidence intervals than those methods without bias correction, such as the percentile method. Besides, although the BC bootstrap confidence intervals require a limited normality assumption in estimating the biasing constant, the assumption is less restrictive than the normality assumption in the LRT, as well as in other confidence interval approaches that assume that the difference in factor loadings (or other parameters) is normally distributed (e.g., Meade & Bauer, 2007).

In the following sections, a step-by-step demonstration is first provided to show how BC bootstrap confidence intervals can be established for testing metric invariance across groups using Mplus (Muthén & Muthén, 1998-2010). This demonstration also shows how the factor-ratio test can be conducted. This Mplus procedure is then extended to testing scalar invariance. This demonstration further shows how the list-and-delete method can be used to identify sets of invariant items if scalar invariance is rejected for at least one factor-ratio test. Finally, the Mplus procedure is extended to testing other levels of ME/I including the tests for equivalence in uniqueness variance, factor variance, factor covariance, and latent means.

We recommend the use of Mplus because it is simpler for creating BC bootstrap confidence intervals for differences. Using Mplus, researchers can directly create a new parameter in an Mplus program, such as the difference in the factor loadings for a particular combination of the referent and argument of a construct across groups, and then generate a BC bootstrap confidence interval for the difference. As multiple new parameters can be created in a single Mplus program, a single model will suffice for testing all the combinations of referents and arguments, thus simplifying the procedures demonstrated by Cheung and Rensvold (1999) that require repeated model estimation. Although Mplus requires fewer steps and is more straightforward than LISREL in estimating the BC bootstrap confidence intervals, LISREL performs better in controlling the overall Type I error rate with Bonferroni adjustments for the α level for the item-level invariance tests. Although the LISREL procedures for estimating BC bootstrap confidence intervals to investigate ME/I are complicated, they are similar to those used to examine the significance of mediation effects proposed by Lau and Cheung (2012).1

All of the demonstrations in this teaching note use the Work Orientations data set published by the International Social Survey Program in 1989 from an international project that began in 1984. The demonstrations use two groups: respondents in the United Kingdom (n = 645) and respondents in the United States (n = 820). The measurement model to be tested for equivalence consists of three constructs: quality of job context (JX: ξ1), quality of job content (JC: ξ2), and quality of work environment (WE: ξ3). Each construct is measured by four items, each of which is scored on a Likert-type scale ranging from 1 to 5 (refer to Cheung & Rensvold, 1999, pp. 12-13, for the items). As the three constructs measure different perceived aspects of work, they are allowed to be correlated in the model. The ME/I tests include all three constructs in one measurement model and simultaneously examine the model’s fit to the multigroup data. Figure 1 illustrates the measurement model.

sec.title: Testing Metric Invariance by BC Bootstrapped Confidence Intervals with Mplus
sec.p: The syntax for testing metric invariance at the item level with Mplus Version 6 can be found in Appendix A. This is a configural invariance model with new parameters for differences in factor loadings across groups. As good model fit is a prerequisite for meaningful interpretation of BC bootstrap confidence intervals, it is necessary to ensure that the configural invariance model shows adequate model fit. In this case, the configural invariance model shows acceptable model fit, χ2(102) = 399.613, CFI = 0.932, RMSEA = 0.063, SRMR = 0.050, suggesting that configural invariance has been established.

In the syntax, the DATA and VARIABLE commands provide information about the data set and the variables to be analyzed. The MODEL command describes the measurement model to be estimated. In Mplus, two variations of the MODEL command can be used: MODEL and MODEL followed by a label such as “MODEL US” in our example. As the default for Mplus in multigroup analysis is measurement invariance (invariant factor loadings and intercepts), the use of MODEL and MODEL followed by a label specifies the differences in factor loadings and/or intercepts in the models across groups. Specifically, although MODEL describes the overall model to be estimated for each group, MODEL followed by a label describes how the model for a group with the designated label differs from the overall model (Muthén & Muthén, 1998-2010, pp. 73-74). Also shown in Appendix A is that the factor loadings of y 1, y 5, and y 9 are set to unity in both groups to provide the units of measurement for the three latent variables. Hence, for ξ1, y 1 is the referent; for ξ2, y 5 is the referent; and for ξ3, y 9 is the referent. Consider the first construct, ξ1. The label LX21A is assigned to

The MODEL CONSTRAINT command and the NEW option are used to assign labels to the newly created parameters, that is, the differences in factor loadings across groups. The parameter LX1D21 is created by the NEW option and is defined as LX1D21 = LX21A – LX21B under the MODEL CONSTRAINT command for testing the difference in λ21 with y 1 as the referent. Similarly, the new parameters LX1D31 and LX1D41 are created for testing the difference in λ31 and the difference in λ41, respectively, while y 1 is the referent.

According to the factor-ratio test, all items are used as the referent in an iterative manner. After using y 1 as the referent, y 2 is used as the referent for ξ1. Cheung and Rensvold (1999) suggest modifying the syntax with y 2 as the referent and rerunning the model. This method can be somewhat labor intensive (Johnson et al., 2009). When Mplus is used, rerunning the model becomes unnecessary. Instead, one can directly create new parameters containing the difference in factor loadings with other referents in the same Mplus program (see Appendix B for the mathematical derivations). If the bootstrap sample sizes are too small, two researchers using the same data set may generate different confidence intervals because the bootstrap samples generated by each researcher may be different (Gleser, 1996; MacKinnon et al., 2004). In view of this limitation, Cheung and Lau (2008) recommend the use of a bootstrap sample size of 500 to 1,000. Therefore, in the ANALYSIS command, the statement “BOOTSTRAP = 1000” is used to generate 1,000 bootstrap samples. Finally, in the OUTPUT command, BC bootstrap confidence intervals are estimated with the statement “CINTERVAL(BCBOOTSTRAP).”

Table 1 presents part of the Mplus output file. Mplus provides not only the estimates of the parameters but also the 90%, 95%, and 99% BC bootstrap confidence intervals for the estimates. As multiple null hypotheses are tested for each construct, α adjustment (α divided by the number of item-level tests per construct) is necessary so that the overall Type I error rate for each construct can be minimized. In this case, as the overall α level is set at .05 and there are six item-level tests in each construct, the adjusted α level should be .05/6 = .0083. The use of 99% BC bootstrap confidence intervals is thus preferred. As shown, the confidence intervals for all new parameters related to ξ1 contain zero. For example, the 99% BC bootstrap confidence interval for LX1D21 is between –0.761 and 0.220, whereas the 99% BC bootstrap confidence interval for LX1D31 is between –0.930 and 0.525. These results suggest that the factor loadings are not significantly different across the U.K. and U.S. groups, which further implies that factor loadings of all items for the construct are equivalent across the two national groups regardless of which item is being used as the referent. Metric invariance thus exists for this construct. The same pattern of results is obtained for the other two constructs, indicating that metric invariance has been achieved for the three constructs across the two national groups.

caption.p: Sample Output File of Bias-Corrected Bootstrap Confidence Intervals for Testing Metric Invariance Using Mplus

sec.p: In this demonstration, all of the items are metric invariant across the groups. However, in cases where metric invariance fails, researchers can employ the list-and-delete method to identify the set of invariant items (Rensvold & Cheung, 2001). The use of the list-and-delete method is demonstrated in the following scalar invariance test.

sec.title: Testing Scalar Invariance by BC Bootstrapped Confidence Intervals With Mplus
sec.p: The previous demonstration shows how the BC bootstrap confidence intervals approach can be used for testing metric invariance. It also shows how the factor-ratio test can be conducted such that all combinations of referents and arguments are tested simultaneously in a single Mplus program. Similar to selecting a referent item to define the scale of the latent variable, the selection of the referent item also defines the latent mean difference across groups. If an item with a noninvariant intercept is selected as the referent, then other items will demonstrate different latent mean differences and scalar invariance will be rejected. Hence, it is important to identify all scalar invariant items before comparing latent means. To avoid failing to detect noninvariant intercepts across groups, the approach proposed by Cheung and Rensvold (1999) for testing all combinations of referents and arguments for metric invariance is extended to testing scalar invariance. In other words, each item is used as the referent in an iterative manner such that all combinations of referents and arguments are tested.

The Mplus syntax for testing scalar invariance as well as the equivalence of uniqueness variances, factor variances, and factor covariances using BC bootstrap confidence intervals is presented in Appendix C. This is the metric invariance model with new parameters for examining differences in item intercepts across groups. If an item is identified as having significantly different factor loadings across groups in the previous step, the factor loadings of this item will be freely estimated, while the factor loadings of other items will be constrained to be equal in the partial metric invariance model. The partial metric invariance model will be used instead of the metric invariance model for estimating the BC bootstrap confidence intervals for the differences in item intercepts. If an item has different factor loadings across groups, it is assumed that the intercepts of the item will also be different across groups and will not be tested for scalar invariance (Cheung & Rensvold, 2000). The metric invariance model in this example shows adequate model fit: χ2(111) = 410.207, CFI = 0.931, RMSEA = 0.061, SRMR = 0.052. While this demonstration pays specific attention to testing scalar invariance, the results of the tests for equivalence of uniqueness variances, factor variances, and factor covariances are presented in the last part of this section. The MODEL command in the Mplus syntax describes the measurement model to be estimated. Items y 1, y 5, and y 9 are selected to be the referents, and their factor loadings are fixed to unity in both groups for standardization. The following syntax is used for testing scalar invariance for the first construct ξ1:

In a similar manner, the new parameter TAU2D4 is created to test the difference in τ4 when y 2 is chosen as the referent, and TAU3D4 is created to test the difference in τ4 when y 3 is the referent. A similar set of new parameters is constructed for ξ2 and ξ3 using different items as the referents. Next, in the ANALYSIS command, the statement “BOOTSTRAP = 1000” is used to generate 1,000 bootstrap samples. Finally, in the OUTPUT command, the statement “CINTERVAL(BCBOOTSTRAP)” is used to estimate the BC bootstrap confidence intervals.

Table 2 presents the sample Mplus output containing the estimates and the 90%, 95%, and 99% BC bootstrap confidence intervals for the constructed new parameters. Again, because multiple null hypotheses are tested, 99% BC bootstrap confidence intervals are interpreted to minimize the overall Type I error rate. For ξ1, it is shown that the 99% BC bootstrap confidence intervals for TAU1D4 and TAU2D3 contain zero. Hence, when y 1 is used as the referent, τ4 is invariant across groups. Likewise, when y 2 is the referent, τ3 is invariant across groups.

caption.p: Sample Output File of Bias-Corrected Bootstrap Confidence Intervals for Testing Scalar Invariance Using Mplus

sec.title: Identifying Noninvariant Items Using the List-and-Delete Method
sec.p: The list-and-delete method (Rensvold & Cheung, 2001, pp. 38-40) is employed to identify sets of invariant items. The procedure involves three steps. In Step 1, list out all possible sets of invariant items for an n-item construct. For instance, there are 11 possible sets of invariant items for a four-item construct, as listed in the first column of Table 3 . There is 1 set with all four items, plus 4 sets with three items and 6 sets with only two items. In Step 2, for each item-level test being rejected, one deletes all possible sets of items listed in Step 1 that contain both the reference and argument items. This occurs because the rejection of invariance in the factor-ratio test implies that either the reference or the argument or both are noninvariant. For example, if Item 2 is identified as noninvariant when Item 1 is used as the reference, it is not feasible to have both Items 1 and 2 in the final set of invariant items. Hence, we need to “delete” all sets of items that include Items 1 and 2. Step 3 involves eliminating the possible sets that are subsets of larger combinations. For example, if the set with Items 2, 3, and 4 and the set with Items 2 and 4 both remain after Step 2, we delete the set with Items 2 and 4 because it is a subset of the set with Items 2, 3, and 4. The application of the procedure to identify noninvariant items for ξ1 is demonstrated in Table 3.

caption.p: The List-and-Delete Procedure for Identifying Noninvariant Items in Testing Scalar Invariance

fn.p: Note: The four indicators of ξ1 are numbered 1 through 4. Significant factor-ratio tests identified from the bias-corrected bootstrap confidence intervals approach are TAU1D2, TAU1D3, TAU2D4, and TAU3D4. Column 1 shows the results of applying Step 1 of the list-and-delete procedure. Columns 2 to 5 show the results of applying Step 2 of the procedure. The combinations of items that are eliminated are struck through. The sets of invariant items that remain after applying the three steps of the procedure are combinations (1, 4) and (2, 3).

sec.p: In Table 3, the first column, “Original candidate combinations,” shows the results of following Step 1: listing all combinations of the four items for ξ1. These combinations include any combinations containing four, three, and two items, for a total of 11 combinations. Noninvariant items are deleted in Step 2. The result in Table 2 shows that TAU1D2 is significant, which implies that Item 2 is noninvariant when Item 1 is used as the referent. The second column of Table 3 shows the results of applying Step 2 to delete all possible sets that contain the reference and argument items in a significant factor-ratio test. In this step, all combinations listed in Step 1 that contain both Items 1 and 2 are deleted. Hence, combinations (1, 2, 3, 4), (1, 2, 3), (1, 2, 4), and (1, 2) are deleted accordingly. These deleted combinations are struck through. The third column shows the result of applying Step 2 to the second significant factor-ratio test TAU1D3, which implies that Item 3 is noninvariant when Item 1 is used as referent. All remaining combinations in the second column are examined and those that contain both Items 1 and 3 are deleted, thus deleting the additional combinations of (1, 3, 4) and (1, 3). Up to this stage, only five combinations remain: (2, 3, 4), (1, 4), (2, 3), (2, 4), and (3, 4), as shown in the third column. When Step 2 is applied to the third significant factor-ratio test on TAU2D4, the remaining combinations that contain both Items 2 and 4 are deleted. Therefore, two more combinations are deleted: (2, 3, 4) and (2, 4). As shown in the fourth column, only three combinations remain: (1, 4), (2, 3), and (3, 4). Finally, when the last significant factor-ratio test on TAU3D4 is considered, the combination (3, 4) is further deleted, as shown in the final column. As a consequence, the application of Step 2 deletes all but two combinations of items: (1, 4) and (2, 3). Step 3 involves deleting the remaining combinations from Step 2 that are subsets of larger combinations. In this demonstration, as no subsets of larger combinations remain after applying Steps 1 and 2, Step 3 is not applicable. Eventually, two combinations of invariant items are identified: (1, 4) and (2, 3). When the same number of items exists in all sets, the choice of combination should be made based on theoretical interpretation and the research question (Cheung & Rensvold, 1999).

When ξ2 is analyzed, the 99% BC bootstrap confidence intervals for TAU5D7, TAU6D7, and TAU7D8 do not contain zero. Accordingly, τ7 is noninvariant when y 5 is used as the referent, and τ7 is noninvariant when y 6 is used as the referent. Also, τ8 is noninvariant when y 7 is the referent. The results of the list-and-delete procedure suggest that the combination (5, 6, 8) is a set of invariant items. Finally, for ξ3, the 99% BC bootstrap confidence intervals for TAU10D11 and TAU11D12 do not contain zero, which suggests that τ11 is noninvariant when y 10 is the referent, and τ12 is noninvariant when y 11 is the referent. When the list-and-delete method is applied, two combinations of invariant items are identified: (9, 11) and (9, 10, 12). The combination (9, 10, 12) is preferred to the combination (9, 11) because the former contains one more invariant item than the latter. With more invariant items, the results of comparing the latent means receive stronger support.

Before proceeding to compare the difference in latent means, one important question to be addressed is whether the partial metric and/or scalar invariance warrants further ME/I tests. Although some researchers posit that comparison of latent means should be conducted only in the presence of complete support for metric and scalar invariance (e.g., Bollen, 1989; Millsap & Hartog, 1988), other researchers suggest that only partial metric and scalar invariance is required (e.g., Byrne et al. 1989; Steenkamp & Baumgartner, 1998). Nevertheless, there has been limited discussion of the specific criterion regarding the minimal number or proportion of invariant items required for the establishment of partial ME/I. Reise et al. (1993), for instance, suggest that “a majority of the items on a given latent variable should have loadings that are invariant across groups” (p. 556). Vandenberg and Lance (2000) recommend that partial metric invariance is acceptable only when (a) a minority of indicators are identified as noninvariant, (b) a strong theoretical basis exists for partial metric invariance, and (c) there is cross-validation evidence showing the viability of partial metric invariance. Yet, Steenkamp and Baumgartner (1998, p. 81) specifically state that a minimum of two items, one of which is the reference indicator, have to be invariant before researchers can meaningfully compare latent means across groups. As shown in the mathematical derivation in Appendix D, testing the equivalence of item intercepts across groups is identical to testing whether the observed mean difference in the referent item is consistent with the observed mean difference in the argument item when adjusted by a scaling factor. Hence, the issue is not how many noninvariant items are identified but how many invariant items there are, because the more items that exist for the same construct that show scalar invariance, the stronger the evidence supporting the same latent mean difference across groups. Regarding this issue, we recommend that researchers have a majority of items (i.e., more than half) identified as invariant before proceeding to test the equivalence of latent means. Ployhart and Oswald (2004, p. 38) provide an excellent framework for determining whether item intercepts should be constrained to be equal or freely estimated from a theoretical, rather than a statistical, consideration.

We also conducted the tests for invariance of uniqueness variances, factor variances, and factor covariances based on the Level 2 metric invariance model obtained from the results of the metric invariance test. The results are shown in Table 4 . When the 99% BC bootstrap confidence intervals are interpreted, it can be seen that all the uniqueness variances are not significantly different between the two national groups except for TD11. Specifically, the confidence interval for the difference in uniqueness variance for y 11 is between –0.357 and –0.032. Table 4 also shows that the equivalence of factor variances is achieved because all confidence intervals for the differences in factor variances contain zero. Finally, while the covariances of ξ1 and ξ3 and those of ξ2 and ξ3 are equivalent between groups, the covariances of ξ1 and ξ2 are significantly different between the U.K. and the U.S. groups because the confidence interval is between 0.011 and 0.156. One may refer to Vandenberg and Lance’s article (2000, pp. 36-40) for detailed explanations of each ME/I test, interpretations of test results, and possible causes of failing invariance. For the sequence of tests for the ME/I of second-order constructs, researchers can estimate the BC bootstrap confidence intervals for differences in the parameters in a second-order model across groups listed by Cheung (2008, p. 598).

caption.p: Sample Output File of Bias-Corrected Bootstrap Confidence Intervals for Testing Equivalence of Uniqueness Variances, Factor Variances, and Factor Covariances Using Mplus

sec.title: Testing the Equivalence of Latent Means by BC Bootstrapped Confidence Intervals With Mplus
sec.p: The previous demonstration shows that the list-and-delete method can be used by researchers to identify sets of invariant items across groups. This section illustrates an Mplus procedure for comparing latent means using the BC bootstrap confidence intervals approach. In our demonstration, since only two out of the four items (not majority) in ξ1 are identified to be invariant, comparison of latent means of ξ1 across groups is not conducted. On the other hand, since a majority of (three out of four) items of both ξ2 and ξ3 are found to be invariant, their latent means are compared across groups. The sample Mplus syntax, which is the partial scalar invariance model for examining the differences in latent means across groups, is presented in Appendix E. This partial scalar invariance model allows the intercepts of the items with noninvariant intercepts identified in the previous step (y 2, y 3, y 7, and y 11) to be freely estimated. This model demonstrates acceptable model fit with χ2(116) = 415.929, CFI = 0.931, RMSEA = 0.059, and SRMR = 0.053, suggesting that partial scalar invariance is achieved. As only invariant items can be used as referents, y 1, y 5, and y 9 are chosen to be the referents in the MODEL command. The item intercepts of y 4, y 6, y 8, y 10, and y 12 are then constrained to be invariant across the U.K. and U.S. groups, while those of the remaining items are freed for estimation. Similar to the syntax for testing metric and scalar invariance, in the ANALYSIS command, the statement “BOOTSTRAP = 1000” is used to generate 1,000 bootstrap samples. In the OUTPUT command, the statement “CINTERVAL(BCBOOTSTRAP)” is used to estimate the BC bootstrap confidence intervals.

Table 5 presents the sample Mplus output. The latent mean values in the U.K. group

Accordingly, the BC bootstrap confidence intervals for the latent mean values in the U.S. group are equivalent to the BC bootstrap confidence intervals for the difference in latent mean values across the two national groups. Since there is only one test for latent means difference for each construct, the α level is not adjusted and the 95% BC bootstrap confidence intervals are interpreted. sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: Whenever comparisons of survey results are made across groups, researchers should first demonstrate evidence of measurement equivalence. Otherwise, any conclusions made without such evidence tend to be weak, as the findings are subject to the alternative interpretation that the measurement is different across groups (Steenkamp & Baumgartner, 1998). This teaching note recommends and demonstrates the use of BC bootstrap confidence intervals as an alternative method to the LRT, ▵CFI, and MI approaches for testing ME/I. The demonstrations also suggest that the list-and-delete method used to identify noninvariant items that was proposed for testing metric invariance (Rensvold & Cheung, 2001) can be easily extended to testing scalar invariance across groups. While demonstrations of comparing factor loadings, item intercepts, and factor means are provided, the Mplus procedures can also be extended to testing the equivalence of uniqueness variances, factor variances, factor covariances, and direct and indirect path coefficients.

sec.title: Sequence of ME/I Tests
sec.p: In this teaching note, we follow the sequence of ME/I tests recommended by Cheung and Rensvold (2002). There are eight tests in total, categorized into three different levels. First, configural invariance has to be established. With configural invariance, researchers can move on to the Level 1 test, where BC bootstrap confidence intervals for the differences in factor loadings are estimated for testing metric invariance. Next, with full or partial metric invariance established, researchers can proceed to Level 2, where the demonstrated BC bootstrap confidence interval method can be used to examine the invariance of uniqueness variances, factor variances, factor covariances, item intercepts, or path coefficients across groups. If full or partial scalar invariance is established, researchers can construct BC bootstrap confidence intervals for the differences in latent means at Level 3, examining whether the latent means are significantly different across groups.

sec.title: Comparisons With Other Methods
sec.p: We also tested the measurement invariance of our example with the LRT, the ▵CFI thresholds, and the MI method by Yoon and Millsap (2007) and compared the results with those obtained from the demonstrated BC bootstrap confidence intervals approach. The results pertaining to the LRT and the ▵CFI approaches from Mplus using a threshold of ▵CFI > 0.002 (Meade et al., 2008) are presented in Table 6 . The results of the LRT are indicated by the columns of ▵χ2 and p values. If a p value is smaller than .01, the corresponding ▵χ2 value is in bold and italics in Table 6, and the LRT test then suggests that the null hypothesis of invariance be rejected. The results using the ▵CFI > 0.002 threshold are indicated by the column of ▵CFI. The ▵CFI values that are larger than 0.002 are in bold and italics in Table 6, and they indicate that the null hypothesis of invariance is rejected. Furthermore, to make comparisons easier, the item-level scalar invariance tests in the first column are in bold and italics if the BC bootstrap confidence interval approach suggests noninvariance between groups.

caption.p: Testing Measurement Invariance Using LRT and ▵CFI (>0.002)

fn.p: Note: A test in bold and italics indicates that the item intercepts are identified to be significantly different between groups using the bias-corrected bootstrap confidence interval approach. A ▵χ2 in bold and italics indicates that the item intercepts are identified to be significantly different between groups using the likelihood ratio test. A ▵CFI in bold and italics indicates that the item intercepts are identified to be significantly different between groups using the ▵CFI threshold of 0.002 (Meade, Johnson, & Braddy, 2008). CFI = comparative fit index; ▵CFI = change in comparative fit index; RMSEA = root mean square error of approximation; SRMR = standardized root mean square residual.

sec.p: As shown in Table 6, the first test was the test for configural invariance, followed by the test for metric invariance. Both LRT and ▵CFI values suggesting configural and metric invariance were established. A test for scalar invariance for the full model was then conducted. Since the results did not support full scalar invariance (p value = .000; ▵CFI = 0.015), construct-level tests for scalar invariance were then conducted, with one test for each construct. As scalar invariance was not achieved for each construct (p values = 0.000; ΔCFI > 0.002), item-level scalar invariance was further tested for each item with different referent items. It can be seen that the LRT results are comparable to those obtained from the BC bootstrap confidence interval approach. Likewise, it can be seen that the ▵CFI threshold (0.002) and the BC bootstrap method differ only in the test of TAU11D12. The BC bootstrap method suggests a significant difference between groups, whereas the ΔCFI value (0.001956) suggests otherwise. If, however, the ▵CFI threshold of 0.01 (Cheung & Rensvold, 2002) is used, there may not be sufficient power, and only full scalar invariance is rejected. Nevertheless, it should be noted that Mplus calculates CFI based on the minimum fit function χ2. The ▵CFI > 0.002 threshold recommended by Meade et al. (2008) was derived with CFI based on the weighted least squares χ2 using LISREL 8.0. We also ran the analysis using LISREL 8.7 and got results similar to those using Mplus.

The results pertaining to the MI method are presented in Table 7 . In this analysis, five iterations of tests were conducted. In each iteration, the item that had the largest MI is in bold, italics, and underlined in Table 7. As Table 7 shows, τ7 was the one with the largest MI (23.927) in the first iteration and thus freed for estimation in the following iterations. In the second iteration, τ11 was the one with the largest MI (15.351). It was therefore freed for estimation in the following iterations. In the third and fourth iterations, τ1 and τ4 had the largest MIs, respectively. In the fifth iteration, all MI values were smaller than 5.0, and thus no further tests were conducted. In short, the MI method suggests that the item intercepts of y 7, y 11, y 1, and y 4 are noninvariant across groups, therefore showing similar results as the BC bootstrap approach. Nevertheless, it should be noted that the MI method tends to have high Type I error and inadequate power (Yoon & Millsap, 2007). Although the results from different methods for detecting noninvariant items are similar in this example, the results are based on one empirical data set and cannot be generalized to other situations. A more comprehensive comparison of these methods is needed in future studies.

caption.p: Testing Scalar Invariance Using Yoon and Millsap’s Modification Index Method

fn.p: Note: Numbers in bold, italics, and underlined have the largest modification index in that iteration. Fit indices for the full scalar invariance model (Model I): χ2(120) = 485.478; comparative fit index = 0.916; root mean square error of approximation = 0.064; standardized root mean square residual = 0.055.

sec.p: Our results also demonstrate the importance of selecting an appropriate referent and how the factor-ratio test can solve this problem. Table 6 shows that if an inappropriate item is used as the referent, incorrect identification of noninvariant items may result. For instance, if y 7 was used as the referent for ξ2, items y 5, y 6, and y 8 were identified as noninvariant, but in fact, our factor-ratio test result showed that only y 7 was noninvariant. Likewise, if y 9 was chosen to be the referent for ξ3, no item was identified to be noninvariant. Our factor-ratio test, however, showed that y 11 was in fact noninvariant. These results therefore reinforce the importance of incorporating the factor-ratio test into the examination of ME/I.

Apart from these comparison results, the problem stemming from nonconvergence may suggest another reason why the use of the BC bootstrap confidence interval approach is preferred to the ▵χ2, ▵CFI, and MI approaches, which all require estimating the constrained model. In SEM, nonconvergence or improper solutions are usually caused by small sample sizes, models of too high complexity, model misspecifications, and sometimes inappropriate starting values (Bollen, 1989, pp. 254-256). When testing metric invariance, for instance, factor loadings are constrained to be equivalent across groups in the constrained model. If these equality constraints are not correct in the sample, the constraints will lead to model misspecification, which, in turn, creates a higher chance of improper solutions or no converging solution being obtained. As found in a recent simulation (Meade et al., 2008), the problem of nonconvergence is more profound in the constrained scalar invariance model than in the constrained metric invariance model. As all item intercepts are constrained to be equal, in addition to the equality constraints on factor loadings in the constrained scalar invariance model, the model is therefore more likely to be misspecified. Without a converged solution to model estimation, cross-group comparisons become impossible. On the other hand, as the BC bootstrap confidence intervals are estimated in the unconstrained model, nonconvergence is less likely to happen.

We have demonstrated how the BC bootstrap confidence interval approach can be used to compare latent means across groups. An alternative method, which is also the most frequently used method for comparing means, is to compute a summated index (e.g., summated score or average score) that represents the latent variable of interest and then compare the mean difference across groups. Although this summated index is conceptually simple, it faces several disadvantages. One major shortcoming is that it does not take into account the relative strengths of the relationships between items and constructs, that is, the factor loadings. When the factor loadings are not uniform, it is inappropriate to form composite scores by adding or averaging item responses (Kim & Mueller, 1978, pp. 64-66). Another shortcoming pertains to the rationale for testing metric invariance. If the test for metric invariance shows that the factor loadings are noninvariant across groups, it is inconsistent to treat the relationships as if they were the same, which is the effect of unit weighting as in the calculation of a summated index (Cheung, Murrmann, Murrmann, & Becker, 2004; Cheung & Rensvold, 1998). Also, if measurement invariance fails, not only may selection in the groups being compared suffer from selection errors (Millsap, 2007), but the effect size, direction, and statistical significance of the mean differences may also be obscured (Sharma, Durvasula, & Ployhart, 2012).

To further illustrate the problems, we calculated the difference in the means between the U.S. and U.K. groups using average scores by ignoring the measurement invariance problem. For ξ2, the difference is –0.0365 (p = .291), and for ξ3, the difference is –0.0200 (p = .672). Compared with the BC bootstrap results shown in Table 5, it can be seen that the estimate of the mean difference for ξ2 even changes sign. A closer examination at the item means differences shows that the observed means of Items 5, 6, and 8 of the U.S. group are higher than those of the U.K. group by 0.010, 0.000, and 0.054, respectively. On the other hand, the observed mean of Item 7 of the U.S. group is lower than that of the U.K. group by 0.211. This inconsistency in mean difference across items was picked up by the scalar invariance test, which showed that Item 7 is noninvariant. Hence, Item 7 was effectively removed in the comparison of latent means by allowing the intercepts of Item 7 to be freely estimated in both groups. In short, comparing the summated indices averages the inconsistency in mean differences across items for a construct, which in turn may lead to inaccurate estimation of mean differences if measurement invariance fails (Sharma et al., 2012). As a consequence, if practitioners rely on summated indices without considering measurement invariance, they may be using inaccurate difference scores, which in turn may lead to inaccurate decisions.

sec.title: Item-Level Versus Scale-Level Tests
sec.p: The demonstrated bootstrap method represents an item-level test, similar to the tests under the item response theory framework. These item-level tests differ from the LRT and ▵CFI approaches, which usually examine the scale-level invariance first and only conduct item-level tests when the scale-level invariance is rejected (e.g., Cheung & Rensvold, 1999). Because scale-level tests can better control overall Type I errors than item-level tests do, adjustments for Type I error are necessary when conducting item-level tests, which is one of the limitations facing the demonstrated BC bootstrap confidence interval approach. However, a major problem associated with scale-level tests is that if only a few items in a multi-item construct have noninvariance, the scale-level tests may not have enough power to identify the existence of the noninvariance (Meade & Kroustalis, 2006). In addition, compared to scale-level tests, item-level tests for the equivalence of factor loadings across groups are more precise (Meade & Lautenschlager, 2004a). Moreover, if studies make use of multifactor surveys and researchers are interested in testing the whole multifactor model, the use of item-level tests becomes particularly important because the noninvariance in the items in a particular factor may be obscured by the invariance in the items in all other factors if scale-level tests are conducted (Meade & Kroustalis, 2006). Therefore, we encourage researchers to conduct item-level tests using the proposed BC bootstrap confidence intervals method.

sec.title: Factors Affecting the Power of the BC Bootstrap Confidence Interval Test for ME/I
sec.p: The width of the BC bootstrap confidence intervals is noteworthy. Some of the confidence intervals obtained in our demonstrations are wider than others. For instance, the confidence interval for LX1D31 is between –0.930 and 0.525, whereas that for LX1D41 is between –0.667 and 0.380. Practically, the wider a confidence interval, the less precision it has and the less powerful it is in testing true difference. Regarding the factors that affect the size of confidence intervals, sample size, the number of items per factor, item communality (the proportion of variance in an item explained by the latent factor), and the size of the factor loading (a ratio to the factor loading of the referent) may play a critical role (Meade & Bauer, 2007; Meade & Lautenschlager, 2004b). As the sample size increases, the more likely it is the sample will resemble the true population. The confidence intervals established tend to be smaller. As the number of items per construct increases, the standard error tends to decrease, thus resulting in a smaller confidence interval. Similarly, as the item communality increases, the variation in the item decreases and the confidence interval established is likely to be smaller. The investigation of the factors affecting the width of confidence intervals represents a promising direction for future studies. Another avenue for future studies concerns the effect of unequal sample size on the width of BC bootstrap confidence intervals in ME/I tests. It has been found that unequal sample size across groups will lower the power of LRT and ▵CFI in testing ME/I (Chen, 2007), and the same should happen in tests with BC bootstrap confidence intervals. Future studies are needed to examine the impact of sample size and the difference in sample size across groups on the size of BC bootstrap confidence intervals in ME/I tests.

sec.title: Limitations
sec.p: The demonstrated procedures for testing ME/I are not without limitations. As the BC bootstrap confidence interval approach can examine only item-level metric, scalar, and uniqueness invariance, the α level should be adjusted to minimize the overall Type I error rate. However, we believe this limitation does not curtail the advantages of the proposed procedures. In fact, failure to achieve full invariance is not uncommon in cross-cultural research or when a construct is measured using many items (Steenkamp & Baumgartner, 1998). Under such circumstances, researchers need to identify which parameter (or parameters) is causing noninvariance. Hence, the proposed procedures that involve multiple comparisons can help researchers easily detect noninvariance.

A related limitation stems from the adjustment of α. Unlike the LISREL procedures that allow manual adjustment of α with the use of the Bonferroni correction, the Mplus procedures do not allow such adjustment. For a four-item construct and an overall construct-level Type I error at 5%, the adjusted α for each item test should be .83% (.05/6). Hence, the 99.17% BC bootstrap confidence intervals should be used. As such, the 99% BC bootstrap confidence intervals become the closest and best choice, and we believe that the lack of manual adjustment of the α level in Mplus may not, in fact, be a critical concern for four-item constructs. However, as the number of items for a construct increases, the overall Type I error rate will be higher. If 99% BC bootstrap confidence intervals are used for testing metric invariance or scalar invariance, the overall Type I error rate will be 0.0585 (i.e., 1 – .996) for a four-item construct; 0.0956 (i.e., 1 – .9910) for a five-item construct, and 0.1399 (i.e., 1 – .9915) for a six-item construct. If Bonferroni correction is used (α divided by the number of tests), the Type I error rate will be 0.04897 for a four-item construct, 0.04889 for a five-item construct, and 0.04885 for a six-item construct. Although Bonferroni adjustment of α will lower the power, if a moderate sample size is used for each group in the cross-group comparison (e.g., n = 200) and if a simple pairwise comparison is to be conducted, sufficient power is likely to be achieved. In reality, this limitation is not unique to the procedures demonstrated in this teaching note but exists in all other methods that employ the factor-ratio test to identify noninvariant items, including LRT.

The assumptions underlying the BC bootstrap confidence interval approach lead to additional limitations. Specifically, BC bootstrap confidence intervals require a sample to be a good representative sample of the population distribution. If the sample size is too small, this assumption is unlikely to hold. Hence, researchers are again advised to have at least a moderate sample size (e.g., 200) for each group (Yung & Bentler, 1996). Another assumption is that the data are collected using simple random sampling, as represented by the simple bootstrap method. If stratified or cluster sampling is used, more complex bootstrap methods have to be employed.

The use of only two groups in our demonstrations represents another limitation of the demonstrated procedures. In cross-group comparisons, researchers may be interested in comparing more than two groups. The BC bootstrap confidence interval procedures do not allow for overall tests across three or more groups. However, if researchers are interested in testing a specific set of latent contrasts, the same BC bootstrap confidence intervals procedures described above can be applied by creating new parameters as contrasts across multiple groups, instead of the differences between two groups. Researchers may also be interested in conducting latent pairwise comparisons. Specifically, new parameters can be created for each pair of groups for pairwise comparisons in the Mplus program, but the α level should be adjusted accordingly.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: Before making comparisons of survey responses across groups, researchers need to correctly identify all noninvariant items to avoid inaccurate conclusions being drawn from the comparisons. Considering the importance of the tests for ME/I in cross-group comparisons, we extend the BC bootstrap confidence interval approach using Mplus for testing specific mediation effects proposed by Lau and Cheung (2012) to examine measurement invariance across groups. Not only can this approach provide an estimate of the difference between two groups, but it also can provide a confidence interval for the estimate. Unlike the LRT and ▵CFI approaches that require separate model estimations for each item-level test, we demonstrate that the BC bootstrap confidence interval approach allows all item-level tests for all constructs to be tested in one model estimation. We also demonstrate the importance of conducting the factor-ratio test when selecting reference items. Moreover, the proposed Mplus procedures allow researchers to conduct factor-ratio tests more easily in one model estimation than they would using the procedures proposed by Cheung and Rensvold that require repeated model estimations (Cheung & Rensvold, 1999; Rensvold & Cheung, 2001). Finally, the application of the list-and-delete method enables the noninvariant items to be accurately identified across groups.

Items that are identified as noninvariant can be handled in several ways. First, the items can be simply removed from the measure. This option, however, should be considered with caution, as it can be atheoretical and can be seen as capitalizing on chance (Cheung & Rensvold, 1999). The second option is to continue the tests with partial metric and/or scalar invariance. This option is recommended when latent means are being compared or when structural models cannot be established under the conditions of full invariance (e.g., Byrne et al., 1989). However, the results must be interpreted with caution, especially when there are more than a few noninvariant items. Finally, researchers may treat invariance as a source of information about the meaningful differences across groups. For ME/I research to advance, researchers need to investigate and understand the situations in which invariance exists or fails (Cheung & Rensvold, 1999; Meade, Michels, & Lautenschlager, 2010). Whatever option is adopted, the correct identification of noninvariant items is a prerequisite.
